required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Electrical Stimulation for the Treatment of Pain Following Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) Using the SPRINT System
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Case Series Study of SPR Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS) Therapy for the Treatment of Pain Following Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) Utilizing Preoperative Lead Placement

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if electrical stimulation (small levels of electricity) can safely and effectively reduce pain following total knee replacement (or total knee arthroplasty (TKA)). This study involves a device called the SPRINT System. The SPRINT System delivers mild electrical stimulation to nerves in the leg that received the knee replacement. The SPRINT System includes a small wire (called a "lead") that is placed through the skin in the upper leg. It also includes a device worn on the body that delivers stimulation (called the SPRINT Stimulator).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative Day 0 to 28 (first 4 weeks following Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA))
primary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to complete daily diaries to track their average pain intensity while walking during the past 24 hours over a 7-day period on an 11-point numerical rating scale where 0 represents "No Pain" and 10 represents "Pain as bad as you can imagine." The average score for each diary period was calculated across subjects, and the mean scores for weeks 1-4 is reported.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants That Experienced at Least One Study-Related Adverse Event
primary_outcome.time_frame: Total of 21 months (from when the first subjects enrolled to when the last subject completed the study)
primary_outcome.description: At each study visit following the baseline assessment at Visit 1, subjects were questioned if any changes in their medical status or condition has occurred since their previous visit. If the subject experienced a change that was an adverse event, an Adverse Event Form was completed by the site. The number of subjects that experienced at least one study-related adverse event is reported here.

secondary_outcome.measure: Average Knee Pain Over the Last 24 Hours
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative Day 0 to 28 (first 4 weeks following Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA))
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to complete daily diaries to track their average pain intensity in the past 24 hours over a 7-day period on an 11-point numerical rating scale where 0 represents "No Pain" and 10 represents "Pain as bad as you can imagine." The average score for each diary period was calculated across subjects, and the mean score for weeks 1-4 is reported.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative Day 0 to 28 (first 4 weeks following Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA))
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to complete daily diaries to track their average pain intensity at rest in the past 24 hours over a 7-day period on an 11-point numerical rating scale where 0 represents "No Pain" and 10 represents "Pain as bad as you can imagine." The average score for each diary period was calculated across subjects, and the mean score for weeks 1-4 is reported.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 4 (Day of Surgery) and Visits 6-11 (weeks 1-6 post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA))
secondary_outcome.description: The amount and type of analgesics used by subjects was recorded in daily diaries. Narcotic usage was converted into a morphine equivalent dosage (MED), which is measured in units of morphine milligram equivalents (MME). Diaries were collected at various visits throughout the study, and for consistency, these data were translated into post-operative days. The average MED was calculated for each subject for the first 42 days (6 weeks) following surgery, and the median of these averages was determined across subjects.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants That Experienced at Least One Opioid-Related Side Effect
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 2 (Lead Placement), Visits 5-13 (in-hospital days through 3-months post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA))
secondary_outcome.description: Throughout the study, subjects were asked if they experienced any side effects related to opioid pain medications. The occurrences of these side effects were recorded and were not reported as Adverse Events. The number of subjects that experienced at least one opioid-related side effect at each visit is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Achieve 90 Degrees Flexion in Affected Knee
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 2 (Lead Placement), Visit 7 (3-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
secondary_outcome.description: Active range of motion (AROM; no assistance from clinical staff) and passive range of motion (PROM; assisted by clinical staff) was assessed with both stimulation on and off. The time that it took subjects to achieve the milestone of 90 degrees of knee flexion in their affected leg is reported.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 5 (In-Hospital), Visit 7 (2-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects began this test from a seated position in a standard chair and were timed while they stood up, walked to a marked point 10 feet away (at a normal, safe pace), returned to the chair, and sat down. Timed Up and Go (TUG) test times are expected to be greater immediately after surgery as compared to baseline.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 7 (2-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
secondary_outcome.description: The total distance that a subject could walk in 6 minutes was recorded, and the mean distance was determined across subjects. 6 Minute Walk Test distances are expected to be reduced immediately after surgery as compared to baseline.
The amount of time it took subjects to walk a fixed distance of 20 meters was recorded.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline on the Western Ontario McMaster University Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 5 (In-Hospital), Visit 7 (2-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
secondary_outcome.description: The Western Ontario McMaster University Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) questionnaire consists of 24 items that evaluate pain, stiffness, and physical functional disability. Each item is scored on an 11-point numerical rating scale from 0 to 10, where higher scores indicate greater pain, stiffness, and disability. For each subject, the scores from each of the 24 items were summed to calculate the subject's total score, with a minimum score of 0 and a maximum score of 240. Percent change from baseline was calculated for each subject at each time point (i.e., value at Visit 5 vs. Baseline rating, value at Visit 7 vs. Baseline rating, value at Visit 11 vs. Baseline rating, and value at Visit 13 vs. Baseline rating). The median percent change across subjects was determined. Negative values indicate worsening since Baseline, while positive values indicate improvement from Baseline. Percent improvement = 100 x ([rating at each study visit]-[rating at baseline]) / [rating at baseline].

secondary_outcome.measure: Knee Pain Interference With Daily Activities
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 2 (Lead Placement), Visits 5-13 (in-hospital days through 3-months post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA))
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to rate the degree to which their knee pain has interfered with 7 different aspects of their daily life on a scale from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating greater interference. Those 7 scores were averaged for each subject to provide an overall pain interference score, with a possible range of 0 to 10 with higher scores indicating greater interference. The median score was then calculated across subjects.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Reporting Meaningful Improvement, Minimal or No Change, or Meaningful Worsening on the Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) Survey
secondary_outcome.description: The Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) asks subjects to rate their improvement with treatment on a 7-point scale ranging from "very much worse" to "very much improved" as compared to before their knee replacement surgery. The subjects combine all the components of their experience into one overall score. Ratings of Much- or Very Much Improved are considered Meaningful Improvements; similarly, ratings of Much- or Very Much Worse are categorized as Meaningfully Worse.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 11 (6-weeks post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 13 (3-months post-TKA)
secondary_outcome.description: The Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS) questionnaire has 13 questions that assess rumination, magnification, and helplessness. Subjects are asked to think back on painful experiences in the past and reflect on how often they had specific thoughts or feelings. Each of the 13 questions is scored on a 5-point scale where 0 represents "not at all," and 4 represents "all the time." The scores from each question were summed for each subject to provide a total PCS score, with a possible range from 0 to 52 with higher scores indicating a greater tendency to catastrophize pain (i.e. a higher score indicates a worse outcome). The median scores were then calculated across all subjects.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Meet Recovery Milestones up to Three Months Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Day of Surgery through completion of milestone or 3-months from Day of Surgery, whichever came first
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were queried weekly from the date of their Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) until they met specific, post-surgical recovery milestones. Participants were queried up through the time at which they meet each milestone or through their completion of the study, whichever came first (up to three months post-surgery).
Subjects completed a sponsor-developed survey with questions pertaining to their feelings about the SPRINT Stimulation System as a method for managing post-surgical pain.

arm_group.description: All study subjects will have up to 2 Smartpatch Leads placed in their leg that underwent total knee replacement, will use the SPRINT Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS) System, and will receive electrical stimulation.

intervention.description: The SPRINT System is an Investigational Device which delivers mild electrical stimulation to nerves in the leg that underwent lead placement. The SPRINT System includes a small wire (called a "Lead") that is placed through the skin in the upper leg. It also includes a device worn on the body that delivers stimulation (called the SPRINT Stimulator).

criteria.textblock:
Key Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 21 years old
- Scheduled to undergo a primary unilateral total knee replacement procedure
Key Exclusion Criteria:
- Body Mass Index (BMI) > 40 kg/m2
- Compromised immune system based on medical history
- History of valvular heart disease
- Implanted electronic device
- Joint or overlying skin infection of the affected limb
- History of recurrent skin infections
- Bleeding disorder
- Allergy to skin surface electrodes and/or medical‚Äêgrade adhesive tapes
- Pregnant

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment began September 2015 (with first subject enrollment in October 2015) and was concluded in February 2017. Subjects were screened for the study from a pool of candidates scheduled to undergo a primary unilateral total knee replacement procedure.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: After obtaining informed consent, subjects were evaluated for eligibility.

group.title: Consented Subjects
group.description: These subjects signed an informed consent form and met all eligibility criteria.

baseline.population: This group includes subjects that were consented, met eligibility criteria, and received Leads.

group.title: Enrolled/Received Leads
group.description: This group includes subjects that were consented, met eligibility criteria, and received Leads.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Reason for Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
measure.description: The reason that each subject was scheduled to undergo a primary unilateral total knee arthroplasty (also known as total knee replacement).

The average score for each diary period was calculated across subjects, and the mean scores for weeks 1-4 is reported.

The average score for each diary period was calculated across subjects, and the mean score for weeks 1-4 is reported.

outcome.title: Amount of Analgesic Usage
outcome.description: The amount and type of analgesics used by subjects was recorded in daily diaries. Narcotic usage was converted into a morphine equivalent dosage (MED), which is measured in units of morphine milligram equivalents (MME). Diaries were collected at various visits throughout the study, and for consistency, these data were translated into post-operative days. The average MED was calculated for each subject for the first 42 days (6 weeks) following surgery, and the median of these averages was determined across subjects.
outcome.time_frame: Visit 4 (Day of Surgery) and Visits 6-11 (weeks 1-6 post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA))
outcome.population: Data was not available for: one subject during Post-op Week 1, three subjects for Weeks 2 and 4, four subjects during Weeks 3 and 5, and for seven subjects during Post-op Week 6.

group.description: These subjects were consented and met eligibility criteria, received leads, and underwent their scheduled Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) procedures.

outcome.title: Time to Achieve 90 Degrees Flexion in Affected Knee
outcome.description: Active range of motion (AROM; no assistance from clinical staff) and passive range of motion (PROM; assisted by clinical staff) was assessed with both stimulation on and off. The time that it took subjects to achieve the milestone of 90 degrees of knee flexion in their affected leg is reported.
outcome.time_frame: Visit 2 (Lead Placement), Visit 7 (3-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
outcome.population: Three subjects did not meet 90 degrees of flexion with stimulation on by Visit 11 (End of Treatment) for both active range of motion (AROM) and passive range of motion (PROM). Data was not collected for four subjects for PROM with stimulation on and for three subjects for AROM with stimulation on.

group.title: Underwent Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
group.description: These subjects were consented and met eligibility criteria, received leads, and underwent their scheduled Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) procedures.

measure.title: Time to Achieve 90 Degrees Flexion in Affected Knee
measure.description: Active range of motion (AROM; no assistance from clinical staff) and passive range of motion (PROM; assisted by clinical staff) was assessed with both stimulation on and off. The time that it took subjects to achieve the milestone of 90 degrees of knee flexion in their affected leg is reported.

Data was not collected for four subjects for PROM with stimulation on and for three subjects for AROM with stimulation on.

outcome.title: Timed Up and Go (TUG) Test
outcome.description: Subjects began this test from a seated position in a standard chair and were timed while they stood up, walked to a marked point 10 feet away (at a normal, safe pace), returned to the chair, and sat down. Timed Up and Go (TUG) test times are expected to be greater immediately after surgery as compared to baseline.
outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 5 (In-Hospital), Visit 7 (2-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
outcome.population: Data was not collected for two subjects at Visit 5 and another subject was physically unable to complete the test. Data was not collected for one subject at Visit 7.

group.title: Underwent Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
group.description: These subjects were consented and met eligibility criteria, received leads, and underwent their scheduled Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) procedures.

measure.title: Timed Up and Go (TUG) Test
measure.description: Subjects began this test from a seated position in a standard chair and were timed while they stood up, walked to a marked point 10 feet away (at a normal, safe pace), returned to the chair, and sat down. Timed Up and Go (TUG) test times are expected to be greater immediately after surgery as compared to baseline.
measure.population: Data was not collected for two subjects at Visit 5 and another subject was physically unable to complete the test. Data was not collected for one subject at Visit 7.

outcome.title: 6 Minute Walk Test (6MWT)
outcome.description: The total distance that a subject could walk in 6 minutes was recorded, and the mean distance was determined across subjects. 6 Minute Walk Test distances are expected to be reduced immediately after surgery as compared to baseline.
outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 7 (2-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
outcome.population: One subject at Visit 1 and two subjects at Visit 7 were physically unable to complete the test. Data was not collected for an additional subject at Visit 7.

group.title: Underwent Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
group.description: These subjects were consented and met eligibility criteria, received leads, and underwent their scheduled Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) procedures.

measure.title: 6 Minute Walk Test (6MWT)
measure.description: The total distance that a subject could walk in 6 minutes was recorded, and the mean distance was determined across subjects. 6 Minute Walk Test distances are expected to be reduced immediately after surgery as compared to baseline.
measure.population: One subject at Visit 1 and two subjects at Visit 7 were physically unable to complete the test. Data was not collected for an additional subject at Visit 7.

outcome.title: Fixed Distance Walk Test
outcome.description: The amount of time it took subjects to walk a fixed distance of 20 meters was recorded.
outcome.population: One subject at Visits 1 and 5 was physically unable to complete the test. Data was not collected for two additional subjects at Visit 5, and another subject walked a fixed distance greater than 20 meters during the test so their results are not comparable.

group.title: Underwent Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
group.description: These subjects were consented and met eligibility criteria, received leads, and underwent their scheduled Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) procedures.

measure.population: One subject at Visits 1 and 5 was physically unable to complete the test. Data was not collected for two additional subjects at Visit 5, and another subject walked a fixed distance greater than 20 meters during the test so their results are not comparable.

outcome.title: Percent Change From Baseline on the Western Ontario McMaster University Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC)
outcome.description: The Western Ontario McMaster University Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) questionnaire consists of 24 items that evaluate pain, stiffness, and physical functional disability. Each item is scored on an 11-point numerical rating scale from 0 to 10, where higher scores indicate greater pain, stiffness, and disability. For each subject, the scores from each of the 24 items were summed to calculate the subject's total score, with a minimum score of 0 and a maximum score of 240. Percent change from baseline was calculated for each subject at each time point (i.e., value at Visit 5 vs. Baseline rating, value at Visit 7 vs. Baseline rating, value at Visit 11 vs. Baseline rating, and value at Visit 13 vs. Baseline rating). The median percent change across subjects was determined. Negative values indicate worsening since Baseline, while positive values indicate improvement from Baseline. Percent improvement = 100 x ([rating at each study visit]-[rating at baseline]) / [rating at baseline].
outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 (Baseline), Visit 5 (In-Hospital), Visit 7 (2-weeks Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)), Visit 11 (6-weeks Post-TKA), Visit 13 (3-months Post-TKA)
outcome.population: Data was not collected for two subjects at Visit 5.

outcome.title: Time to Meet Recovery Milestones up to Three Months Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
outcome.description: Participants were queried weekly from the date of their Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) until they met specific, post-surgical recovery milestones. Participants were queried up through the time at which they meet each milestone or through their completion of the study, whichever came first (up to three months post-surgery).
outcome.time_frame: From Day of Surgery through completion of milestone or 3-months from Day of Surgery, whichever came first
outcome.population: Data were not available for climbing stairs and discharge destination for 3 subjects and for discharge criteria and clearance to drive for one. Data were not collected for clearance to work in 2 subjects, and 10 subjects were retired. Opioid cessation data were not collected for 1 subject, and 2 subjects did not cease opioids during the study.

group.title: Underwent Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
group.description: These subjects were consented and met eligibility criteria, received leads, and underwent their scheduled Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) procedures.

measure.title: Time to Meet Recovery Milestones up to Three Months Post-Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
measure.description: Participants were queried weekly from the date of their Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) until they met specific, post-surgical recovery milestones. Participants were queried up through the time at which they meet each milestone or through their completion of the study, whichever came first (up to three months post-surgery).
measure.population: Data were not available for climbing stairs and discharge destination for 3 subjects and for discharge criteria and clearance to drive for one. Data were not collected for clearance to work in 2 subjects, and 10 subjects were retired. Opioid cessation data were not collected for 1 subject, and 2 subjects did not cease opioids during the study.

class.title: Able to climb half flight of stairs

outcome.title: Subject Satisfaction Survey
outcome.description: Subjects completed a sponsor-developed survey with questions pertaining to their feelings about the SPRINT Stimulation System as a method for managing post-surgical pain.
outcome.population: Two subjects did not answer the question regarding the amount of time it took to feel pain relief from stimulation.

group.title: Underwent Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
group.description: These subjects were consented and met eligibility criteria, received leads, and underwent their scheduled Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) procedures.

measure.title: Subject Satisfaction Survey
measure.description: Subjects completed a sponsor-developed survey with questions pertaining to their feelings about the SPRINT Stimulation System as a method for managing post-surgical pain.

class.title: Tolerated Lead placement with some/no discomfort
Would recommend stimulation therapy to a friend
Prefer stimulation therapy to pain medication use
Wanted stimulation for longer time period

reported_events.time_frame: 21 months (from the time the first subject was enrolled to when the last subjects completed the study)

group.title: Enrolled/Received Leads
group.description: This group includes subjects that were consented, met eligibility criteria, and received Leads.

event.description: One event was study-related, and the other was not
One event was study-related, and the other two were not
Three events were study-related, and one was not
Two events were not study-related, and the relationship to the study was unable to be determined for the other event
Relationship to study unable to be determined

event.sub_title: Small dehiscence at Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) surgical site
Skin irritation or bruising at Lead exit site

event.description: Two events were study-related, and the other one was not
Relationship to study unable to be determined

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
